# More detailed Why ## Working directories and Paths - directory means folder - important concepts when you interact with computers without clicking ![Allison Horst cartoon "code gets the blame"](/r4babs1/week-6/images/code_gets_the_blame.jpg){fig-alt="A charactered has slipped on a banana skin and is blaming the code character but the real culprits, holding bananas, are mismanaged files, navigating your computing and typos"} ## Working directories - Default folder a program will read and write to. - You will have some understanding Word demo ## Paths - location of a file/folder - appear in the address bar of explorer/finder and browsers demo . . . - when you can't click, you need the path ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} chaffinch <- read_table("chaff.txt") ``` ::: ## Absolute path ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} chaffinch <- read_table("C:/Users/er13/OneDrive - University of York/Desktop/Desktop/undergrad-teaching-york/BIO00017C/BIO00017C-Data-Analysis-in-R-2020/data/chaff.txt") ``` ::: . . . Only exists on my computer! ## Relative paths - location of a file/folder relative to the working directory - If my working directory is BIO00017C-Data-Analysis-in-R-2020: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} chaffinch <- read_table("data/chaff.txt") ``` ::: ## RStudio Projects - Sets the working directory to be the project folder - Code is portable: you send someone the folder and everything just works! # More detailed what ## demo # Summary - You teach using R directly - Please use RStudio projects - Consistency - Easier for students, Easier for you - Fewer laptop-out-the-window moments - You teach or supervise students using R - it's a just a folder
